pullRequest.body:
Add definition of a Hopf algebra. For FLT.

This generally looks good, just some style suggestions. The TODO comment about S being an antiautomorphism would be great to have in this PR, but if the plan is to get some imperial undergrads working on them, I'm fine with this being merged without them.

> This generally looks good, just some style suggestions. The TODO comment about S being an antiautomorphism would be great to have in this PR, but if the plan is to get some imperial undergrads working on them, I'm fine with this being merged without them.

Indeed some Imperial undergrads have proved this and I was hoping to let it be a separate PR.

This looks good to me!

bors merge

bors d+

Thanks!

I think the references.bib is not going to pass CI until you run `bibtool` against it to clean up the format.

bors d+

Thanks!

I think the references.bib is not going to pass CI until you run `bibtool` against it to clean up the format.
This looks like a problem (that `(R := R)` is needed here). Can we have another version in which is is an explicit argument?
This is now `antipode_apply` and `R`, `A` are explicit in `antipode`.

```suggestion
* <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bialgebra>

## TODO

* Uniqueness of Hopf algebra structure on a bialgebra (i.e. if the algebra and coalgebra structures agree then the antipodes must also agree).

* S(1)=1 and S(ab)=S(b)S(a), so in particular if A is commutative then S is an algebra homomorphism.

* If H is commutative then S is necessarily a bijection (and I think its square must be the identity?)

References for these facts: Christian Kassel "Quantum Groups" (Springer GTM), around Prop III.3.1, Theorem III.3.4 etc.

```

I don't understand the choice of these field names. Could you replace them with something with underscores?

Perhaps `mul_rTensor_comul`, etc?

```suggestion
    LinearMap.mul' R A âˆ˜â‚— S.rTensor A âˆ˜â‚— comul = Algebra.linearMap R A âˆ˜â‚— counit
```
and below

Maybe
```suggestion
  antipode : A â†’â‚—[R] A
```
and have `S` be `notation`?
This also lets you delete the `def antipode` below.

Wait -- the point of `antipode` is that it makes `R` and `A` explicit. Are you still suggesting I change `S` to `antipode`? Should I change it to `antipode'` and leave `def antipode`? If we want `antipode R A` to be the canonical spelling of `S` should I also change the other fields e.g. `mul_rTensor_comul` -> `mul_rTensor_comul'` and then restate with `antipode`?

In some sense that ship has already sailed; `comul` and `counit` don't make `R` and `A` explicit either, and we make do with `(R := R)` in a bunch of places.

My inclination would be to follow that pattern for now, and make a follow-up PR that adjusts all of them to be explicit at once (using the pattern you describe).
Perhaps its time to open a Lean4 issue asking for adjusting argument explicitness on typeclass projections.
I've followed the pattern, I'll open an issue soon.

I've started with a Zulip post.

https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/RFC.3A.20adjust.20argument.20explicitness.20on.20typeclass.20projections/near/423072202

```suggestion
theorem mul_rTensor_comul_apply (a : A) :
    LinearMap.mul' R A (S.rTensor A (H.comul a)) = algebraMap R A (H.counit a) :=
```
and below: wrapping at `:` is a bit clearer than wrapping at `=`, and `algebraMap` is the simp-normal form.

Naming instance arguments is usually a bad pattern:
```suggestion
variable {R : Type u} {A : Type v} [CommSemiring R] [Semiring A] [HopfAlgebra R A]
```
This means that the comul and counit in theorems like `mul_rTensor_comul_apply` are now `Coalgebra.comul` etc (which is fine by me, but is this OK?)
They're the same `comul` . I'm pretty sure `H.comul` is desugaring to `H.toBiAlgebra.toCoalgebra.comul` anyway.
Oh I can quite believe this -- I was just checking it was OK.
can you add this to `references.bib`?

I guess you can just copy

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/65037e3470a82737b4ce82d6a0c4e4f7534fbf47/docs/references.bib#L1812-L1825

with a different chapter number / doi / etc

You already added it, but only chapter 2:
```bibtex
@InBook{          kasselTensorProducts1995,
  title         = {Tensor {{Products}}},
  booktitle     = {Quantum {{Groups}}},
  author        = {Kassel, Christian},
  year          = {1995},
  volume        = {155},
  pages         = {23--38},
  publisher     = {{Springer New York}},
  address       = {{New York, NY}},
  doi           = {10.1007/978-1-4612-0783-2_2},
  urldate       = {2023-09-28},
  collaborator  = {Kassel, Christian},
  isbn          = {978-1-4612-6900-7 978-1-4612-0783-2}
}
```
Should I delete this, replace with a reference to the entire book, and edit your reference to it in RingTheory.TensorProduct, in this PR?
That sounds fine to me too.

```suggestion
* $S(1)=1$ and $S(ab)=S(b)S(a)$, so in particular if A is commutative then S is an algebra homomorphism.
```
or
```suggestion
* `S 1 = 1` and `S (a * b) = S b * S a`, so in particular if A is commutative then S is an algebra homomorphism.
```
so that this looks nice in the docs.
I think for providing downstream instances, it's going to be more helpful to have as a simp lemma that `antipode R R = .id`.

```suggestion
* `HopfAlgebra.antipode` : The `R`-linear map `A â†’â‚—[R] A`
```
Good catch!
`S` here and elsewhere should be `antipode`
OK we are now completely `S`-free!

This docstring will appear on one of the two fields, and doesn't really convey anything anyway.
On the other hand, these lemma names should contain `antipode`:
```suggestion
  mul_antipode_rTensor_comul :
    LinearMap.mul' R A âˆ˜â‚— antipode.rTensor A âˆ˜â‚— comul = (Algebra.linearMap R A) âˆ˜â‚— counit
  mul_antipode_lTensor_comul :
    LinearMap.mul' R A âˆ˜â‚— antipode.lTensor A âˆ˜â‚— comul = (Algebra.linearMap R A) âˆ˜â‚— counit
```
as should the `apply` versions below.

```suggestion
```
